text: Anna "Anno" O'Rahilly (née Rahilly) (17 February 1873 – 1958) was an Irish revolutionary and Cumann na mBan member, republican prisoner and hunger- striker active in the period from 1916 to 1923. Born in Ballylongford, Co. Kerry to grocer and nationalist public representative Richard Rahilly and Ellen Mangan, she was a sister of the 1916 leader The O'Rahilly and the Cummann na mBan leader Nell Humphreys (née Rahilly).http://theirishrevolution.ie/26845-2/ She was educated at Ursuline College Waterfordhttp://www.ursulinewaterford.ie/wp/alumni/http://www.waterfordmuseum.ie/exhibit/web/Display/article/382/26/Waterfords_Revolutionary_Women_19161922_Anno_and_Nell_ORahilly.html and became a member of the Gaelic League. Like The O'Rahilly, she changed her name from the original Rahilly. In April 1914 she was one of a small group of women present at the founding of Cumann na mBan in Wynne's Hotel, Dublin.http://www.waterfordmuseum.ie/exhibit/web/Display/article/382/26/Waterfords_Revolutionary_Women_19161922_Anno_and_Nell_ORahilly.html Following the death of her brother The O'Rahilly in combat in 1916 she was arrested and detained in the aftermath of the Easter rising. She provided the first money to be handled by Dail Eireann in 1919, a loan for £2000.http://humphrysfamilytree.com/ORahilly/anno.htmlhttp://www.generalmichaelcollins.com/life- times/finance/national-loan-191920/ The National Library of Ireland holds a letter from her appealing for money on behalf of republican prisoners' dependents.http://catalogue.nli.ie/Record/vtls000540469 During the Civil war, on 4 November 1922 she was accidentally shot in the family home in Ailesbury Road by Ernie O'MalleySee http://www.waterfordmuseum.ie/exhibit/web/Display/article/382/26/Waterfords_Revolutionary_Women_19161922_Anno_and_Nell_ORahilly.htmlSee https://books.google.ie/booksid=EiibBAAAQBAJ&pg;=PT54&lpg;=PT54&dq;=anno+o%27rahilly&source;=bl&ots;=TqLFkU7Q_M&sig;=9udiR63qFILB1Bh8NgQ9qmlPdtE&hl;=en&sa;=X&ved;=0ahUKEwiDnt_i573TAhUrCMAKHSf8BjYQ6AEISTAI#v=onepage&q;=anno%20o'rahilly&f;=false After her recovery, she was detained for the rest of the civil war in Mountjoy Prison, Kilmainham Gaol and the North Dublin Union, where she was on hunger strike in October–November 1923.http://humphrysfamilytree.com/ORahilly/anno.html ==References== Category:1873 births Category:1958 deaths Category:People of the Easter Rising Category:People from County Kerry Category:Cumann na mBan members
title: Anno O'Rahilly
